docs.title: TotalMiner Community Hub
docs.text:
Welcome to the TotalMiner Community Hub (TMCH) — a community-driven documentation site for Total Miner Forge.

This site exists to make Total Miner’s systems easier to understand by organizing community knowledge into clear, readable documentation. Whether you’re new to the game or deep into creative and scripting, TMCH aims to give you reliable explanations without unnecessary complexity.

docs.title: What this site covers
docs.text:
TMCH focuses on documenting systems and mechanics that are often confusing, undocumented, or scattered across different sources, including:

  • Permissions – how access control works and how permissions interact
  • Creative Mode – tools, behaviors, and creative mechanics
  • Scripting – scripting concepts, examples, and limitations
  • Gameplay Systems – mechanics explained in plain language
  • Community Findings – discoveries and behaviors learned through testing

All content is written with clarity in mind and expanded as the community learns more.

docs.title: Who this is for
docs.text:
This site is for: - Players learning how Total Miner systems actually work - Creative builders designing complex worlds - Scripters experimenting with automation and logic - Anyone tired of digging through old forum posts or Discord messages

If you’ve ever thought “why isn’t this written down anywhere?” — this hub is for you.

docs.title: Community-driven
docs.text:
TMCH is a fan-made, community-maintained project. It is not officially affiliated with the developers of Total Miner.

Documentation improves over time through: - Community testing - Shared knowledge - Contributions and corrections

If something is unclear or missing, it’s an opportunity to improve it.

docs.title: Contributing
docs.text:
Contributions are welcome and encouraged.

You can help by: - Fixing typos or unclear explanations - Expanding existing pages - Adding new documentation sections - Sharing discoveries or edge cases

Check the repository README for contribution details.

docs.title: Getting started
docs.text:
If you’re new here, a good place to begin is: - Getting Started – an overview of core systems - Permissions – one of the most important mechanics to understand - Scripting – if you’re interested in automation or logic

Use the navigation on the left to explore.

docs.title: Disclaimer
docs.text: TotalMiner Community Hub is a community documentation project. All game-related names, mechanics, and assets belong to their respective owners.

docs.title: Contributing to TMCH
docs.text:
TotalMiner Community Hub (TMCH) is a community-driven documentation project. Its quality depends on shared knowledge, testing, and small improvements over time.

You do not need to be an expert to contribute.

docs.title: Why contribute?
docs.text:
Many Total Miner systems are: - poorly documented - explained only in chat messages - learned through trial and error

Contributing helps: - prevent knowledge from being lost - make systems easier to understand - reduce repeated questions - improve world stability and server management

Even small changes matter.

docs.title: What you can contribute
docs.text:
You can help TMCH by:

  • fixing typos or grammar
  • clarifying confusing explanations
  • adding examples or edge cases
  • expanding incomplete sections
  • documenting discoveries from testing
  • suggesting new pages or topics

You don’t need to write entire pages — small improvements are encouraged.

docs.title: How to contribute (simple method)
docs.text:
The easiest way to contribute is directly through GitHub.

  1. Navigate to the page you want to improve
  2. Click Edit this page
  3. Make your changes
  4. Submit the pull request

That’s it.

You don’t need to clone the repo or install anything locally.

docs.title: How to contribute via Discord
docs.text:
If you’re not comfortable editing files:

  • Share discoveries in Discord
  • Point out incorrect or outdated info
  • Suggest topics that need documentation

Documentation improvements often start as Discord discussions.

docs.title: Contribution guidelines
docs.text: To keep the docs consistent and useful:

docs.title: Be accurate
docs.text:
Only document behavior you have: - tested - observed repeatedly - or verified through reliable sources

Avoid assumptions.

docs.title: Be clear
docs.text: Explain why something behaves the way it does, not just what happens.

docs.title: Avoid speculation
docs.text: If something is uncertain: - state that clearly - or leave it undocumented until confirmed

docs.title: Keep it version-agnostic
docs.text: Avoid hardcoding: - exact UI labels - menu paths that may change - version-specific behavior unless necessary

docs.title: Style and tone
docs.text:
TMCH documentation aims to be: - neutral - clear - practical - community-focused

Avoid: - slang - jokes that obscure meaning - unnecessary complexity

docs.title: Reviewing contributions
docs.text:
Contributions may be: - accepted as-is - edited for clarity - discussed for accuracy

Feedback is part of improving quality, not rejecting effort.

docs.title: Reporting issues
docs.text:
If you find a problem but don’t want to edit it yourself: - open an issue on GitHub - or report it in Discord

Be specific about: - what is incorrect - what you expected - where the issue appears

docs.title: Code and scripts
docs.text:
TMCH documentation may include: - example scripts - pseudo-code - configuration explanations

When contributing script-related content: - explain context - note permission requirements - avoid assuming admin access

docs.title: Recognition
docs.text:
Contributors help shape TMCH.

While there is no formal ranking system: - contributors are appreciated - consistent helpers may be recognized in the community - documentation improves because of you

docs.title: Final note
docs.text:
TMCH exists because people choose to share what they learn.

If you’ve ever figured something out the hard way, consider documenting it so someone else doesn’t have to.

Thank you for contributing.

docs.title: Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ)
docs.text: This page answers common questions about Total Miner Forge and the TotalMiner Community Hub (TMCH). If your question isn’t listed here, feel free to ask in the Discord.

docs.title: What is TotalMiner Community Hub (TMCH)?
docs.text:
TMCH is a community-driven documentation site for Total Miner Forge. Its goal is to collect, organize, and explain game systems that are often confusing, undocumented, or spread across different sources.

TMCH is not officially affiliated with the developers of Total Miner.

docs.title: Who maintains TMCH?
docs.text:
TMCH is maintained by members of the Total Miner community. Content is written, reviewed, and expanded as the community learns more about the game.

Anyone can contribute improvements or corrections.

docs.title: Is this documentation official?
docs.text: No. TMCH is a fan-made project. While the information is carefully written and tested, it should be treated as community knowledge rather than official documentation.

docs.title: How accurate is the information?
docs.text:
Accuracy is a priority, but some mechanics are based on: - in-game testing - community discoveries - observed behavior rather than formal documentation

If something is incorrect or outdated, it can be corrected through contributions.

docs.title: How can I contribute to the docs?
docs.text:
There are several ways to help: - Fix typos or unclear explanations - Expand existing pages - Add new pages for undocumented systems - Share discoveries from testing or experimentation

Use the Edit this page link on any page to suggest changes through GitHub.

docs.title: I found a mistake. What should I do?
docs.text:
You can: - Submit a fix using Edit this page - Open an issue on GitHub - Mention it in the Discord so it can be corrected

Even small fixes help.

docs.title: Where should I ask questions?
docs.text:
For questions or discussion: - Join the Discord: https://discord.gg/MWgeYF7Ymp - Post in #help-desk for help - Post in #suggestions for improvements or ideas

The #docs channel contains direct links to all documentation pages.

docs.title: Why doesn’t this page cover everything?
docs.text:
Some systems in Total Miner Forge are: - poorly documented - partially understood - still being explored by the community

TMCH grows over time as more information becomes available.

docs.title: Can I use this documentation for my server or world?
docs.text:
Yes. You’re free to reference or link to TMCH for guides, explanations, or learning purposes.

If you reuse content, crediting the community is appreciated.

docs.title: Will TMCH stay up to date?
docs.text:
TMCH is updated when: - mechanics change - new discoveries are made - contributors submit improvements

The Last updated date on each page shows when it was most recently revised.

docs.title: Is there a changelog?
docs.text: Yes. Major updates and changes are tracked in the Changelog section of the documentation.

docs.title: Will pages have comments or discussions?
docs.text:
At the moment, TMCH does not include comments directly on documentation pages.

Discussion and questions happen primarily in the Discord to keep documentation pages clean and focused.

In the future, TMCH may add page-level discussions using GitHub Discussions (via a system like Giscus) for selected pages where long-term reference discussions are helpful.

If this is added, it will be clearly documented and limited to appropriate sections.

docs.title: Still have questions?
docs.text:
If you didn’t find what you were looking for: - Ask in Discord - Check the relevant system page - Or suggest an FAQ addition

TMCH improves through community feedback.

docs.title: What the Discord is for

The Discord exists to: - ask questions about mechanics, permissions, and scripting - discuss discoveries and edge cases - suggest documentation improvements - get help when something isn’t working - connect with other creators and server owners

docs.title: How to ask good questions
docs.text:
When asking for help, include: - what you’re trying to do - what you expect to happen - what actually happens - permission level involved - whether the area is protected

Clear details lead to faster, better answers.

docs.title: Documentation workflow
docs.text:
The typical flow looks like this: 1. A question or issue comes up in Discord 2. The answer is discussed or discovered 3. The documentation is updated to reflect it

This keeps knowledge from being lost in chat history.

The Discord is a community space. Be respectful, patient, and constructive.

docs.title: Want to help more?

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
In Total Miner Forge, “installation” does not mean downloading mods or configuring files. It refers to the initial setup of a world so that permissions, Creative Mode, and scripting work correctly.

This page walks through the recommended setup process before you begin building or scripting.

docs.title: What this page is for
docs.text:
This guide helps you: - prepare a world for multiplayer or creative work - avoid common permission problems - ensure scripting behaves correctly - prevent accidental damage early on

Think of this as world initialization, not software installation.

docs.title: Step 1: Create the world intentionally
docs.text:
When creating a new world, decide early: - Creative or Survival - Singleplayer or Multiplayer - Experimental vs stable use

These choices affect: - how permissions behave - how scripts execute - how Creative tools are handled

Changing direction later is possible, but planning early saves time.

docs.title: Step 2: Set default permission levels
docs.text:
Before inviting players: - decide what a default player can do - decide who should have elevated access - avoid giving admin permissions too broadly

A common approach: - Guests: limited interaction - Players: normal building - Admins: setup and maintenance only

Avoid using admin accounts for everyday play.

docs.title: Step 3: Protect the spawn area
docs.text:
Spawn is the most important area to protect early.

Recommended protections: - no block breaking - no block placement - limited interaction

This prevents: - accidental damage - griefing - broken systems at spawn

Spawn protection should be set before players join.

docs.title: Step 4: Define key areas
docs.text:
Create and document important areas early, such as: - spawn - system zones - Creative build zones - testing areas

Each area can have: - custom permissions - restricted tools - different interaction rules

Clear area boundaries reduce confusion later.

docs.title: Step 5: Configure Creative Mode access
docs.text:
If using Creative Mode: - decide who can use Creative tools - decide where Creative is allowed - restrict Creative access in finished areas

Creative Mode is powerful and should be treated like a development tool, not a default playstyle.

docs.title: Step 6: Verify scripting works
docs.text:
Before writing complex scripts: - create a simple test script - trigger it as a non-admin player - test inside and outside protected areas

This confirms: - scripts trigger correctly - permissions are respected - area restrictions behave as expected

Do not rely on admin-only testing.

docs.title: Step 7: Test with non-admin accounts
docs.text:
Admins bypass many restrictions.

Always test: - permissions - Creative tools - scripts

using a normal player account.

This step catches most setup issues early.

docs.title: Step 8: Document your setup
docs.text:
If the world is shared or long-term: - write down permission rules - list protected areas - note Creative access rules

Documentation prevents confusion as the world grows.

docs.title: Skipping spawn protection
docs.text: Leads to accidental damage and broken systems.

docs.title: Giving everyone admin
docs.text: Hides permission problems and creates security risks.

docs.title: Testing only in Creative
docs.text: Scripts that work in Creative may fail in Survival.

docs.title: Overlapping area permissions
docs.text: Can cause silent failures and confusing behavior.

docs.title: When setup is complete
docs.text:
Your world is ready when: - players can only do what they should - Creative tools are controlled - scripts behave consistently - protected areas work as expected

From here, you can safely: - build systems - expand the world - invite more players

docs.text: If setup doesn’t behave as expected: - ask in the Discord: https://discord.gg/MWgeYF7Ymp - include permission levels and area details - describe what works and what doesn’t

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Welcome to the TotalMiner Community Hub (TMCH).

This site provides community-driven documentation for Total Miner Forge, focusing on systems that are often confusing, undocumented, or misunderstood.

If you are new to Total Miner Forge or setting up a world for the first time, this page explains how to use the documentation and where to start.

docs.title: What TMCH is
docs.text:
TMCH is a centralized reference for understanding how Total Miner works beyond basic gameplay.

It focuses on: - permissions and access control - Creative Mode and Creative tools - scripting behavior and limitations - world setup and configuration - community-discovered mechanics

TMCH is not official documentation, but it aims to be clear, accurate, and practical.

docs.title: What TMCH is not
docs.text:
TMCH is not: - a mod loader or plugin system - a step-by-step survival guide - a replacement for in-game tutorials - official developer documentation

Instead, it explains how systems behave and why things work the way they do.

docs.title: How the documentation is organized
docs.text: The documentation is organized into a few core sections:

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text:
Covers initial world setup and how to avoid common mistakes early.

Start here if you are: - creating a new world - preparing a multiplayer environment - unsure why systems are not behaving as expected

docs.title: Core Systems
docs.text:
Explains the main systems that control behavior in the game.

Includes: - Permissions - Creative Mode - Scripting

These pages are the foundation for understanding how Total Miner worlds function.

docs.text:
Provides definitions, changelogs, and supporting information.

Includes: - Glossary - Changelog - FAQs

Use this section to look up specific terms or track changes.

docs.text:
If you are new, this order works best:

  1. Installation
  2. Permissions
  3. Creative Mode
  4. Scripting

This sequence mirrors how most worlds are set up and expanded.

docs.title: How to get help
docs.text:
If something does not make sense: - check the relevant system page - read the FAQ - ask in the Discord

Join the Discord here: https://discord.gg/MWgeYF7Ymp

Community discussion helps improve the documentation over time.

docs.title: Contributing to TMCH
docs.text:
TMCH improves through community input.

You can contribute by: - fixing typos or unclear wording - expanding existing pages - adding missing explanations - sharing discoveries from testing

Use the Edit this page link on any page to suggest improvements.

docs.title: Final notes
docs.text:
Total Miner Forge has many systems that interact in subtle ways. Understanding permissions, Creative Mode, and scripting early prevents many common problems later.

This documentation is designed to help you build worlds that are: - stable - secure - understandable - easy to maintain

Welcome to TMCH.

docs.title: Glossary
docs.text:
This glossary defines common terms used throughout Total Miner Forge and the TotalMiner Community Hub (TMCH) documentation.

If a term is missing or unclear, it can be expanded as the community contributes.

docs.title: Area
docs.text: A defined region of the world with its own permissions and rules. Areas are commonly used to protect spawns, systems, shops, or build zones.

docs.title: Area Permissions
docs.text: Rules that apply only within a specific area. These permissions override global permissions while the player is inside the area.

docs.title: Admin
docs.text: A player with elevated permissions that typically bypass many restrictions. Admins are useful for setup and moderation but should not be used for testing permissions or scripts.

docs.title: Creative Mode
docs.text: A mode focused on building, testing, and development. Creative Mode removes many gameplay limitations but still respects permissions and area restrictions.

docs.title: Creative Tools
docs.text: Special tools available in Creative Mode that allow faster building, editing, or testing. These tools are usually restricted due to their power.

docs.title: Execution Context
docs.text:
The environment in which a script runs, including: - who triggered it - where it is running - what permissions apply

Most scripts execute with the permissions of the triggering player.

docs.title: Global Permissions
docs.text: Permissions that apply everywhere in the world unless overridden by area permissions.

docs.title: Guest / Visitor
docs.text: A permission level typically used for new or untrusted players. Guests usually have limited interaction and building abilities.

docs.title: Inheritance
docs.text: The concept that higher permission levels include the abilities of lower levels, unless explicitly restricted.

docs.title: Moderator
docs.text: A trusted role often used to help manage players and enforce rules without full administrative control.

docs.title: Override
docs.text: A permission rule that takes priority over another rule. Area permissions commonly override global permissions.

docs.title: Permission Level
docs.text: A grouped set of permissions that defines what a player can do. Examples include Guest, Player, Moderator, and Admin.

docs.title: Protected Area
docs.text: An area where building, interaction, or modification is restricted to prevent damage or abuse.

docs.title: Script
docs.text: A piece of logic that reacts to events, triggers, or player actions to create custom behavior in a world.

docs.title: Script Trigger
docs.text: The condition that causes a script to run, such as entering an area, interacting with an object, or activating a system.

docs.title: Silent Failure
docs.text: When an action or script fails without showing an error. This is often caused by permission or area restrictions.

docs.title: Survival Mode
docs.text: The standard gameplay mode where players gather resources, manage health, and follow normal progression rules.

docs.title: TMCH
docs.text: Short for TotalMiner Community Hub, the community-driven documentation project for Total Miner Forge.

docs.title: World Owner
docs.text: The individual or group with ultimate control over a world’s settings, permissions, and structure.

docs.title: Want to add a term?
docs.text: If you think a term should be added or clarified: - Suggest it in Discord https://discord.gg/MWgeYF7Ymp - Or use Edit this page to submit an improvement

docs.title: Creative Mode
docs.text:
Creative Mode in Total Miner Forge provides advanced tools and freedoms for building, testing, and designing worlds without normal gameplay limitations.

It is commonly used for: - large builds - custom maps - scripted systems - testing mechanics - server setup and configuration

Because of its power, Creative Mode is tightly controlled by permissions and area restrictions.

docs.title: What is Creative Mode?
docs.text:
Creative Mode removes or relaxes many survival constraints, such as: - resource gathering - block placement speed - tool durability - environmental risks

This allows creators to focus on design and logic, rather than progression.

Creative Mode is not simply “easy mode” — it is a development environment.

docs.title: Creative Mode vs Survival Mode
docs.text:
Creative Mode differs from Survival in several key ways:

Feature Creative Mode Survival Mode Resources Unlimited Gathered Block placement Instant Limited Tool durability None Yes Permissions Required Required Scripting behavior More permissive More restrictive

Scripts and tools that work in Creative may fail in Survival if permissions or restrictions differ.

docs.title: Creative tools
docs.text:
Creative Mode often provides access to special tools that do not exist in Survival.

These tools may allow: - mass block placement or removal - copying and pasting structures - selecting regions - modifying terrain quickly - testing scripts and triggers

Because these tools can easily damage a world, access is usually restricted to trusted users.

docs.title: Permissions and Creative Mode
docs.text:
Creative Mode does not ignore permissions.

Even in Creative: - players can be restricted - areas can be protected - actions can be blocked

Common permission controls include: - who can use creative tools - where creative actions are allowed - which players can enter creative areas

Always verify permission settings when Creative tools do not work as expected.

docs.title: Area restrictions in Creative Mode
docs.text:
Area-based permissions apply fully in Creative Mode.

This allows: - protected spawn areas - restricted system zones - build-only regions - testing areas

A player may be in Creative Mode and still be unable to: - break blocks - place blocks - interact with objects

This is intentional and prevents accidental damage.

docs.title: Creative Mode and scripting
docs.text:
Creative Mode is commonly used to: - test scripts - prototype mechanics - debug systems

However: - scripts may behave differently outside Creative - Creative permissions may hide issues - Survival restrictions can cause scripts to fail later

Always test scripts in their final intended environment.

docs.title: “I’m in Creative but can’t build”
docs.text:
This is almost always caused by: - area restrictions - missing permissions - protected regions

Check the area before changing permissions.

docs.title: “Creative tools aren’t working”
docs.text: Possible causes: - tool access is restricted - player permissions are insufficient - the area blocks creative actions

docs.title: “Everything works for me but not others”
docs.text: Admins often bypass restrictions. Test Creative behavior with: - non-admin accounts - restricted permission levels

docs.title: Separate build and play areas
docs.text:
Keep: - Creative build zones - Survival play zones - system areas

separate and clearly defined.

docs.title: Lock down finished systems
docs.text:
Once a system is complete: - remove Creative access - protect the area - restrict tools

This prevents accidental edits.

docs.title: Document Creative setups
docs.text:
For servers and shared worlds: - document Creative zones - document who has access - document tool permissions

This avoids confusion later.

docs.title: When to use Creative Mode
docs.text:
Creative Mode is ideal for: - world creation - system design - scripting and testing - server configuration

It is not intended for: - normal gameplay - bypassing rules - replacing permissions

Use Creative Mode as a tool, not a shortcut.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
Creative Mode is a powerful environment for building and development, but it relies on: - permissions - area restrictions - careful testing

Understanding how Creative Mode interacts with Permissions and Scripting is key to stable worlds.

docs.text: If Creative Mode isn’t behaving as expected: - Ask in the Discord: https://discord.gg/MWgeYF7Ymp - Describe the permissions and area setup - Share what works and what doesn’t

docs.title: Permissions
docs.text:
Permissions control who can do what in a Total Miner world. They affect building, interaction, scripting behavior, server management, and how players interact with each other.

Understanding permissions is essential for: - multiplayer worlds - public servers - creative projects - preventing griefing or accidental damage

docs.title: What are permissions?
docs.text:
Permissions are a set of rules that determine what actions a player is allowed to perform.

Examples include: - placing or breaking blocks - interacting with objects - using creative tools - running scripts or commands - modifying world settings

Permissions are evaluated every time a player attempts an action.

docs.title: Permission levels
docs.text:
Total Miner uses permission levels to group abilities together. Higher levels generally include the abilities of lower levels.

While exact names and behaviors may vary depending on world configuration, permissions typically follow this structure:

docs.title: Guest / Visitor
docs.text:
• Can explore the world
  • Limited or no building
  • No interaction with protected systems

Used for: - public exploration - first-time visitors - preventing damage

docs.title: Player
docs.text:
• Can build and interact within allowed areas
  • Limited access to tools and systems
  • No administrative control

Used for: - normal survival or creative play - trusted but non-admin users

docs.title: Moderator (if configured)
docs.text:
• Can manage players
  • Can enforce rules
  • May have limited world management abilities

Used for: - staff members - community moderation

docs.title: Admin / Owner
docs.text:
• Full control over the world
  • Can modify permissions
  • Can access all tools and systems
  • Can bypass most restrictions

Used for: - world owners - server administrators

docs.title: Area-based permissions
docs.text:
Permissions can be applied globally or per area.

This means: - A player may be allowed to build in one area - But restricted in another

Area permissions are commonly used for: - spawn protection - shops or hubs - adventure maps - creative plots

When an action is attempted, Total Miner checks: 1. The player’s permission level 2. The permissions of the area they are in 3. Any overrides or special rules

docs.title: Permission inheritance and overrides
docs.text:
Permissions often follow a priority system.

General rules: - Area-specific permissions override global permissions - Higher permission levels override lower ones - Explicit denies usually override allows

Example: - A player is allowed to build globally - But enters a protected area - The area’s restrictions take priority

Understanding overrides is critical when debugging permission issues.

docs.title: “I can build here but not there”
docs.text:
This usually means: - The area has custom permissions - The area overrides global settings

Check the area configuration first.

docs.title: “My script works for admins but not players”
docs.text:
Scripts often respect permission checks. Possible causes: - script actions require higher permissions - script is running in a restricted area - player lacks interaction permissions

Always test scripts using a non-admin account.

docs.title: “Players can break things they shouldn’t”
docs.text:
This usually indicates: - missing area protection - overly broad permissions - permissions applied at the wrong level

Use area-based restrictions to limit damage.

docs.title: Use least privilege
docs.text: Only give players the permissions they actually need.

docs.title: Protect important areas
docs.text: Always protect: - spawn points - command areas - scripted systems - redstone-like logic setups

docs.title: Test with non-admin accounts
docs.text: Admins bypass many restrictions. Testing only as admin can hide permission issues.

docs.title: Document your setup
docs.text:
If you run a server: - document permission rules - keep a record of custom areas - make staff aware of overrides

This prevents confusion later.

docs.title: Permissions and creative mode
docs.text:
Creative mode tools are often restricted by permissions. This prevents: - accidental world damage - abuse of powerful tools - unintended script activation

If creative tools don’t work: - check the player’s permission level - check area restrictions - confirm creative access is enabled

docs.title: Permissions and scripting
docs.text:
Scripts may: - check player permissions - fail silently if permissions are insufficient - behave differently for admins vs players

Always assume scripts run under the permissions of the player triggering them, unless explicitly designed otherwise.

docs.title: Troubleshooting checklist
docs.text:
If something doesn’t work: 1. Check the player’s permission level 2. Check the area permissions 3. Look for overrides 4. Test outside protected areas 5. Test with a non-admin account

Most permission issues are caused by overlapping rules, not bugs.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
Permissions are the backbone of world control in Total Miner.

They determine: - who can build - who can interact - who can manage systems - how scripts behave

A clear permission structure makes worlds safer, cleaner, and easier to manage.

docs.title: Need help?
docs.text: If you’re unsure how permissions are behaving: - Ask in the Discord: https://discord.gg/MWgeYF7Ymp - Check related system pages - Share details about your setup so others can help

docs.title: Scripting
docs.text:
Scripting allows worlds in Total Miner Forge to react dynamically to player actions, events, and game state changes.

Scripts can control: - logic and automation - interactive systems - puzzles and minigames - custom mechanics - server-side behavior

Scripting is powerful, but also tightly limited by permissions and context.

docs.title: What is scripting?
docs.text:
Scripting is the ability to define custom logic that runs in response to: - player actions - triggers or zones - world events - scripted objects or blocks

Scripts do not replace game mechanics — they extend them.

docs.title: Where scripts can run
docs.text:
Scripts typically run in one or more of the following contexts:

  • Trigger zones
  • Interactive objects
  • World-based systems
  • Scripted blocks or entities

The exact trigger depends on how the script is set up.

docs.title: Script execution context
docs.text:
Scripts always run within a context.

This context determines: - who triggered the script - where it is running - what permissions apply

Most scripts execute as the player who triggered them, not as an admin.

This is one of the most common sources of confusion.

docs.title: Permissions and scripting
docs.text:
Permissions heavily affect script behavior.

Common rules: - If a player cannot perform an action normally, a script usually cannot do it on their behalf - Admins may bypass restrictions that normal players cannot - Scripts do not automatically elevate permissions

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
A script tries to place a block: - Admin triggers it → works - Player triggers it → fails

This is usually a permission issue, not a script error.

docs.title: Area restrictions and scripts
docs.text:
Scripts respect area permissions.

If a script runs inside a protected area: - building may be blocked - interaction may be blocked - changes may silently fail

Always check area permissions when debugging scripts.

docs.title: Creative mode and scripting
docs.text:
Creative mode often changes how scripts behave.

In Creative: - restrictions may be relaxed - tools may behave differently - testing is easier

However: - scripts that work in Creative may fail in Survival - Creative permissions may hide problems

Always test scripts in the environment they will be used in.

docs.title: Testing only as admin
docs.text: Admins bypass many checks. This can make broken scripts appear functional.

docs.title: Ignoring permissions
docs.text: If a script fails without errors, permissions are often the cause.

docs.title: Assuming scripts run globally
docs.text:
Scripts usually run locally: - at a position - for a player - within an area

Context matters.

docs.title: Overcomplicating logic
docs.text: Simple scripts are easier to debug and maintain. Complex systems should be broken into smaller parts.

docs.title: Debugging scripts
docs.text:
When a script doesn’t behave as expected:

  1. Test with a non-admin player
  2. Check area permissions
  3. Verify the trigger is firing
  4. Confirm the script context
  5. Test outside protected areas

Most issues are configuration-related.

docs.title: Build small, then expand
docs.text: Start with simple scripts and layer functionality gradually.

docs.title: Separate logic from permissions
docs.text: Design scripts to assume restrictions, not bypass them.

docs.title: Document your scripts
docs.text:
Leave notes explaining: - what the script does - where it runs - what permissions it expects

This helps future maintenance.

docs.title: Avoid silent failures
docs.text: If possible, include feedback so players know when an action fails.

docs.title: When to use scripting
docs.text:
Scripting is ideal for: - automated systems - interactive puzzles - custom mechanics - event-based logic

It is not ideal for: - bypassing core game balance - replacing permission systems - enforcing rules alone

Use scripting alongside permissions, not instead of them.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
Scripting adds depth and flexibility to Total Miner worlds, but it is constrained by: - permissions - area restrictions - execution context

Understanding those constraints is more important than understanding syntax.

docs.title: Need help?
docs.text: If a script isn’t working: - Ask in the Discord: https://discord.gg/MWgeYF7Ymp - Share the script context and permissions - Describe what you expect vs what happens
